content:
Exemption for certain state and local political committees from notification and reporting requirements under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Political committees of state or local candidates and state or local committees of political parties are exempt from notifying the Secretary and reporting requirements. The amendments take effect as if included in Public Law 106-230. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a provision for qualified State or local political organizations. These organizations are defined as political organizations whose exempt functions are solely for influencing or attempting to influence political purposes. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a provision for qualified State or local political organizations whose exempt functions are solely for influencing political purposes, subject to State reporting requirements. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a provision for qualified State or local political organizations to disclose information on expenditures, contributions, and individuals involved. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a provision for qualified State or local political organizations to disclose information on expenditures, contributions, and individuals involved. Organizations are not required to report certain information if it is publicly available and meet specific state law requirements. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 amendment allows qualified State or local political organizations to disclose financial information, with a minimum reporting threshold set at $300. State laws may exempt organizations from reporting certain details. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 amendment requires disclosure of financial information by qualified State or local political organizations, including details such as contributions, occupations, employers, expenditures, purposes, and dates. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 amendment mandates disclosure of financial information by qualified State or local political organizations, including contributions, occupations, employers, expenditures, purposes, and dates. An organization will not lose its qualified status due to minor errors in complying with reporting and inspection requirements if promptly corrected. However, a qualified State or local political organization cannot include a federal candidate or office holder who controls or significantly participates in its direction. The amendment requires disclosure of financial information by State or local political organizations, including contributions, expenditures, and disbursements. It prohibits federal candidates or office holders from controlling or participating significantly in the direction of such organizations. The effective date of the amendments is retroactive to Public Law 106-230. SEC. 3. EXEMPTION FROM ANNUAL RETURN REQUIREMENTS. Income Tax Returns Required Only for Political Organization. Taxable Income paragraph of section 6012(a) of the Internal Revenue Code amended. Income Tax Returns Not Subject to Disclosure. Amendments made to subsections of section 6104 regarding disclosure and public inspection of annual returns. Section 6033 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to require political organizations with gross receipts of $25,000 or more to file annual returns. For qualified State or local political organizations, the threshold is $100,000. Political organizations with gross receipts of $25,000 or more must file annual returns containing specific information required by the Secretary. Exceptions include State or local political party committees, political committees of State or local candidates, and caucuses or associations of State or local officials. Entities required to report under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 include State or local political party committees, committees of State or local candidates, national committees of political parties, campaign committees of the US House of Representatives or Senate, and political committees subject to section 527 for tax purposes. The amendments made by this section, defined in section 301(4) of the Act, allow the Secretary to exempt organizations from filing information returns if deemed unnecessary for efficient tax administration. These amendments are retroactively effective as if included in Public Law 106-230. SEC. 4. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Federal Election Commission, will publicize the impact of the amendments made by this Act and clarify the requirements for filing notifications or reports under section 527 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and reports under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Information provided will be included in relevant forms, instructions, notices, or guidance issued to the public. SEC. 5. Waiver of Filing Amounts: The Secretary may waive taxes or amounts imposed on organizations for failure to comply with requirements if due to reasonable cause. Effective after June 30, 2000.

SEC. 6. Modifications to Section 527 Organization Disclosure Provisions. (a) Unsegregated Funds Not To Avoid Tax.--Paragraph (4) of section 527(i) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include exempt function income as any amount described in subsection (c)(3), whether segregated or not. 
(b) Procedures for Assessment and Collection of Amounts.--Paragraph (1) of section 527(j) is amended to state that the amount imposed shall be assessed and collected in the same manner as penalties under section 6652(c). 
(c) Duplicate Written Filings Not Required.--Subparagraph (A) of section 527(i)(1) is amended. In section 527 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, amendments were made to eliminate duplicate written filings, apply fraud penalties, and specify the contents and filing of reports. Amendments were made to section 527 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to require electronic filing of reports for organizations with contributions or expenditures exceeding $50,000 in a calendar year. Public availability of notices and reports is also mandated. The Secretary must make notices and reports available to the public online within 48 hours of filing. The database must be searchable by organization names, states, zip codes, custodians of records, directors, purposes, related entities, and contributors. The database of notices and reports must include information on organizations, related entities, contributors, employers, recipients of expenditures, contribution ranges, and time periods. Notices must indicate if the organization plans to claim an exemption from certain requirements. The timing of notice in case of material change for organizations claiming exemptions from certain requirements under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is specified. The notice must be given within 30 days of any material change in the required information. Failure to do so will have consequences as outlined in the code. The amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 specify the timing of notice for organizations claiming exemptions. Failure to provide notice of a material change within 30 days will result in consequences outlined in the code. Effective dates for the amendments are also specified. The amendments made by subsections (c), (d), (e)(1), (f), (e)(2), (e)(3), and (g) specify the effective dates for filing reports and notices related to material changes as outlined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by subsection (g) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 specify that material changes on or after the enactment of this Act must adhere to new filing rules. A transition rule allows for a 30-day period for material changes occurring around the enactment date, extending the filing deadline. SEC. 7. EFFECT OF AMENDMENTS ON EXISTING DISCLOSURES. Notices, reports, or returns filed with the Secretary of the Treasury before the enactment of the amendments will continue to be subject to disclosure provisions under section 6104 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
